Depends on your budget and style but start shopping at Uniqlo and Banana Republic (on 40%+ sale) instead for good value basics.

If you are taking cost in into account then Uniqlo is probably the best bang for your buck. 

Grab a pair of selvedge jeans, pima cotton T shirts, airism underwear and undershirts. Then whatever else you need. 

Until you are done losing weight I wouldn't spend too much on more expensive versions. 

After that I would look at the American heritage style brands, particularly from Japan. Iron Heart makes stuff in larger sizes but check the measurement charts carefully since they are a Japanese brand and run a little small. 

For sweatshirts you can't go wrong with Wonderlooper but it comes at a premium.

Unbranded (denim), Bronson (basics/mil-surp), Spier & McKay (suits, OCBDs, knits). 

Those brands are a start but more importantly fit is king. Get a flat measuring tape and find your measurements, then measure clothes that fit you well, and compare them to size guides. Also, looking at reviews will assist in dialing in sizing.

If you really care about sustainability and cheap prices, used is the way to go. Lots of variety of color and styles online. For the price of a new Uniqlo piece, you can get a used Ralph Lauren on eBay and keep something nice and high quality out of the landfill.

Merz B Schwanen, Iron Heart, Dehen 1920, imogene + willie

I would also throw Ralph Lauren and Sunspel in there with the caveat that I feel like they're a little bit overpriced, but they're also more mainstream brands and easier to find.

Everlane and Patagonia are my go-tos for exactly this reason! Both hit your sustainability checkbox and have inclusive sizing. Uniqlo's also surprisingly durable for the price point. Their airism tees have survived like 3 years of constant wear for me without stretching out weird. Just gotta say the quality difference when you upgrade from fast fashion is totally worth it

I might be a little biased since I used to work there, but [National Standards](https://www.ntlstandards.com/) is a Canadian brand that does lots of excellent high-quality mens basics. They have pretty good sales pretty frequently, too.

No one's done the obligatory care instructions disclaimer yet? 

Keep in mind no matter how much you splurge on clothing even the best quality garments will go downhill quickly if not cared for properly. 

Avoid washing too frequently, or infrequently. Avoid washing on excessively long cycles or at high heat.  Generally a good idea to turn most things inside out, but it's especially important for denim.  Avoid the tumble dryer, always line dry, and out of direct sun if it's coloured.

Maybe I am basic but I like Brooks Brothers and J.Crew. Just like everywhere else, not everything is great but I like most of their stuff. I look for sales. I lift weights and have a belly so their XXL/XL stuff works for me without looking odd.

Another option that most guys don’t consider is eBay. 

For a comparable cost (maybe a bit more) to something boxy, bulky and poorly made from The Gap or H&M, you can get yourself into high-end menswear like Todd Snyder or RL. This includes your basics.

And they’re almost exclusively sold by vintage stores with high user reviews. Plus, it’s eBay - so you can make them an offer and many times they’ll jump on it.

I’ve donated years worth of generic crap in favour of a smaller wardrobe largely made up of eBay finds. My stuff fits better and looks better, and holy hell it’s all built to last.

Something to consider.
